{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3501010,"name":"Frank","username":"AlligatorFan3","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/f17d59/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-03T20:27:23.138Z","cooked":"

My team owns one limelight 3, (just the standard one) and this season, we wanted to use the limelight 3 to auto align with the reefs (so having it turn, strafe, and go up to it if the tag is visible).

I was wondering the best way or an efficient way to go about this? Right now, we are just our limelight 3 in the standard tag mode, and have it so when it finds a number, we associate it with a specific angle to turn to, so it will try to turn and strafe in front of it, and when it reaches its setpoints, it will start moving forward. However I wasn’t sure if our method was the best, and if another team had a better method/algorithm for aligning.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-02-03T20:27:23.138Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":262,"reads":241,"readers_count":240,"score":1353.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":484967,"topic_slug":"best-way-to-align-to-an-apriltag-with-one-limelight","display_username":"Frank","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57581,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/best-way-to-align-to-an-apriltag-with-one-limelight/484967/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3501086,"name":"Dan","username":"tekdemo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tekdemo/{size}/138330_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-03T21:22:33.675Z","cooked":"

The best way is one that your team can pull off that gets you scoring.

The optimal way likely involves calculating your field Pose, and then using a path-planning method to navigate to the desired target pose and angle.

In between methods have a lot of room, and your approach is completely valid.

I think the starting point involves identifying the challenges to accurate placing, and whittling down which ones affect you

  • The branch is offset from the april tag; Driving straight at it may put you about a foot from your actual destination
  • The april tag may be out of view as you finish your motion.
  • If you’re a tank drive, you need to approach the target location “square”; otherwise your robot will necessarily need to turn, resulting in a small (but significant) offset from your target.

There’s a few workarounds here you can use, including the easiest, using crosshair offsets in Limelight to “move the target”, and drive to that. Simply set up different pipelines for going to the left/right of the nearby target. (being mindful of course that you might see multiple!)

However, a more advanced level up would be

  • Configure the LL to get you your “robot pose in field space”
  • Generate a “target pose” for the specific scoring position
  • Generate an angle to the target pose
  • Drive to that instead of the april tag.

This additional level of abstraction is a great way to start utilizing april tags and get the hang of working with Pose2d objects. It also involves only a small amount of specialized configuration:

  • Calibrating the LL via the web interface, so that the position/angle are correct to your robot
  • Calculating/recording your Odometry object (which is relatively straightforward mechanically, and well documented in the WPIlib docs for code setup)
  • No specific need to do extensive tuning or modelling of the robot drive itself.

Once you’re driving to arbitrary field positions and not constrained by april tags, you’re well positioned for more complicated things such as driving to a specific position to “line up” for a score, and then driving to the actual scoring position. Or automatically lining up to a cage for a climb. Or moving to full path generation/following.

In the past (before apriltags + odometry) we’ve also done some very unusual lineup routines and processes, but I think getting the hang of working with Poses and odometry generate much more value for the time spent.

I don’t really know if I can help you here, but as far as I know, we’re basing it more on our field pose and using the apriltags for localization and having a more accurate pose. But as far as scoring goes, I think we were planning to have it see the reef, center on a side then go left or right x inches, feet?

Your existing method sounds pretty solid already. I would make the strafe happen continuously (keep running the PID loop) and have the drive control forward/backward motion. That way, they can control the approach while the robot aligns itself.

You could look into 3d pose but it’s not necessary unless the tag gets blocked or you’re trying to do a very fancy auton. And even then, as you score you can reset your odometry to a known pose anyway.

I think using 3d pose is a footgun that can go off in several ways. If your team has already succeeded with it, use it, but most teams will probably be better off sticking with 2d this year.

Can you describe where you are looking to improve accuracy on ? Is it for example slightly off when it thinks its reached and maintained its set point? If this is the case then i’d look into including the offset of limelight in comparison to what you consider to be the correct location. If you are thinking its too slow than look into further optimization in that process theres no reason you cant calculate translation and rotational similar to how teams did target tracking of the hopper in 2022.
